bibl.title: William H. Geary and William Williams v. Defendant. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court for the third Judicial District of Washington Territory

body.p: In the matter of the } petition application of William H. Geary and William Willliams, for a writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Honorable O. Jacobs Chief of Justice of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory and presiding Judge of the 3rd Judicial District
The petition of William H. Geary and William Williams respectfully shows:

That they, the said William H. Geary and William Willliams are restrained of their liberty, in violation of the constitution and the laws of the United States, by J.J.H. Van Bokkelen, in the County name of Jefferson County, Washington Territory

That they have been committed for trial by a United States commissioner upon a charge of mutiny, said to have been commutted on the high seas. Within the admirally and maritime Jurisdiction of the United States -- and that they are held by the said J.J.H. Van Bokkelen to answer the
said preluded charge, on the next regular time of the United States District Court, holding terms at Port Townsend--
That the illegality of their commitment in this:

Your petitioners were seamed on ship- hired for a rayage from San Francisco to Valparaiso - thence to a port of discharge in the United States- that they shipped on said vessel on the 19th day of September 1872. That their royage terminated at port Townsend- that no charge, of any offense, was made against them by the master of said vessel, in the ships official Log book- or the authorities, after the safe arrival of the vessel at Port Townsend. That the master of said vessel complained to no one of their conclusion the voyage - three days after their arrival at Port Townsend and then only- when your petitoners had demanded their discharge and wages- That the examination of said charge before the said Commissioner, was irregular unlawful and void- the said-

commissioners entirely ignoring the laws of the United States. and particulary the entitled "An Act to the appointment of Shipping commissioners by the several circuit courts of the United States to superintend the shipping and discharge of seamen engaged in merchant ships-- belonging to the United States and for the further protection of Seamen. Approved June 7th 1872 - through said act was and is limited on the articles your petitioners signed for the said voyage-

That the only evidence offered to show the commission of any offense was the oral evidence of the said master - which was incompetent and should have been excluded by virtue of the act of congress, herein refered to,

Wherefore, your petitioners pray that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted, directed to the said J.J. H. Von Bokkeler. Commanding him to have the bodies of your petitioners, before your honor at a time and place therein to the specified

to do and receive what sall then be considered by your honor, concerning your petitioner, together with the time and place of cause of their authorization and said writ; and that your petitioners may be restored to liberty
Dated May 5 1873 - William H. Geary and William X Williams
United States of America Third Judicial District } ss of Washington County

William H. Geary and William Willians being duly sworn say That they are the petitoners named in the foregoing petition that they have heard said petition read and know the contents thereof and that the same are true of their own knowledge except as to matters which are therein stated upon information and that as to those matters they believe them to be true.
William H. Geary and William X Williams mark
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of May AD 1873
James Seavey Clerk District Court 3rd Dist W.T at Port
